newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea's Daewoo head probed in arms scandal.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea's Daewoo head probed in arms scandal.

text.p: The chairman of South Korea's sprawling Daewoo Group was summoned by Seoul prosecutors on Tuesday in connection with an arms scandal involving a former defence minister, a Daewoo spokesman said.
Yoon Young-suk, who is also chief executive officer of Daewoo Heavy Industries, returned on Tuesday morning from an overseas business trip, spokesman Kim Yoon-shik said.
Kim emphatically denied any wrongdoing by the company, one of South Korea's leading business conglomerates.
South Korea's main opposition party has alleged an arms dealer was paid bribes of 300 million won ($362,000) by Daewoo Heavy last year to arrange a government purchase of military helicopters.

The dealer paid half the money to former defence minister Lee Yang-ho, who was sacked last week by President Kim Young-sam, according to the allegations made in parliament by the National Congress for New Politics.
Lee Yang-ho has denied the accusations, according to domestic media reports.
The Daewoo spokesman said Daewoo Heavy had paid money to the arms dealer, but not as a bribe.
"The amount did not exceed 300 million won. But it was a commission and not bribery. We have been framed by this fake. That's all we can say at the moment."

At the time, Yoon was chairman of Daewoo Heavy, a leading government arms contractor. Currently, Yoon is in day-to-day charge of the Daewoo group while its powerful founder, Kim Woo-choong, focuses his attention on running its auto division.
Prosecutors denied all comment on the case.
South Korean President Kim Young-sam has ordered an investigation into the scandal.

The affair has embarrassed the president, who has staked his reputation on rooting out corruption in high places in a campaign that has led to the trial and conviction of former presidents Roh Tae-woo and Chun Doo-hwan.
Daewoo founder Kim Woo-choong is currently appealing a two-year jail sentence imposed for bribing Roh. He was one of nine businessmen convicted on similar charges.
The latest scandal has also cast a further pall over a military already reeling from criticism over its failure to intercept a North Korean submarine that intruded last month.

Lee was removed as part of a sweeping reshuffle of the military top brass. The changes were portrayed as a move to shake up a military heirachy accused by politicians and the media of becoming lax and complacent.
The National Congress also accused Lee of leaking classified information on military purchasing plans to the Korean-American arms dealer, Kwon Pyong-ho.
And it alleged he bought expensive jewellery for Roh's daughter on behalf of Lee to secure a promotion for Lee earlier in his career.
Lee Yang-ho has not commented in public on the charges. State media have reported he has been barred from leaving the country.
The submarine ran aground off South Korea's east coast city of Kangnung on September 18. The military was alerted by a taxi driver who saw it looming out of the darkness.
The 26 North Koreans on board fled to the mountains where 22 have been killed or found dead and one captured. A hunt is underway for the three others.

Former President Chun was sentenced to death and Roh to 22-1/2 years in jail after being convicted in August on charges of corruption, mutiny and treason. Both men are currently appealing their convictions.
